content:
Yes, Russia was interested in forging an alliance with Korea in order to expand its influence in East Asia. Russia saw Korea as a potential ally against Japan, which was rapidly expanding its power in the region and challenging Russia's own interests.

During the late 19th and early 20th centuries, Russia pursued a policy of "pan-Slavism," which aimed to promote the interests of Slavic peoples and extend Russia's power and influence throughout Europe and Asia. As part of this policy, Russia sought to forge alliances and partnerships with other countries and peoples that it saw as potential allies.

Russia saw Korea as a potential ally in its efforts to expand its influence in East Asia and counter Japan's growing power. Russia had previously supported Korean independence movements and had been involved in conflicts over Korea, including the Russo-Japanese War of 1904-1905. However, Russia's efforts to forge an alliance with Korea were ultimately unsuccessful, as Japan was able to gain control over Korea and establish a protectorate in 1905.
